ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Observations about English words. Thinking about dialectal differences. Compounding vs. affixation. Functional words and variation.
The course is a good introduction to linguistics through morphology.

I learned about many areas that can be explored in the field of Linguistics. I also learned a little bit about how language changes over time and, more specifically, how English has changed and been influenced by other languages. I also learned more specifics about words and how they form including different types and rules for compounds, phonology, etc.
The concept was an introduction in various linguistic concepts such as morphology and phonology through the prism of the English language.

I developed insight into the morphology of certain English words and the general semantic functioning of different groups of English words. One key insight that Professor Wood emphasized rested on the mindset that no linguistic forms are "wrong," though some might differ from one speaker's experience in an interesting way.
I now have a much greater understanding of where words come from and how our language has developed.
I learned a lot about the basics of morphology, including blends and compounding, changes in language over time, and much more.
Knowledge of the origins and usage of the English language; how to analyze academic papers
An ability to pull apart the English language
I developed a broad base of introductory linguistics that could definitely be applied to harder or more specialized linguistics classes.
I really did learn a lot about linguistics in this class and it was super interesting to do so, given that I am a STEM subject inclined student.
Introduction to English morphology and the way linguists think about words.
I learned about many basic concepts in linguistics, including an introduction to the international phonetic alphabet, phonology, morphology, dialects, and other variations in language.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: chill class; interesting but not difficult; good professor; low workload; interesting guest speakers.

Weaknesses: grading was more opaque than I'd have preferred; more feedback on assignments would have been nice; more structure would also have been nice (for example, a syllabus).
The content is pretty interesting, and the course is not a ton of work. However, some of the lectures feel like they go one a bit too long and there isn't a ton of engagement.

Strengths: Really enjoyed the diversity of topics and the amount of readings was just right. 

Weakness: I found the grading to be too strict at times, especially considering this was just an intro course.

This course succeeded in providing many opportunities to improve your grade and catch up on class material. The course also provided a broad and interesting selection of readings. 

There were some assignments that I didn't feel really contributed that much to my overall understanding, the discussion posts in particular. Since we were already discussing information pretty regularly and actively in class, the discussion posts felt more like a relic from zoom class than a useful teaching tool.
In class discussion was very helpful.
This class was incredible! I loved how creative and fun the assignments were, and how the lectures were filled with opportunity for discussion.

I think the format was not the most conducive to learning; it might have better held my attention and produced more cohesive discussions if it was two 50 min lectures per week and a discussion section. As it was, the class lagged somewhat. I also did not get very good feedback on assignments.

I think the biggest strength of this course is the professor. Jim Wood is simply a wonderful professor and kind person. He taught every lecture with enthusiasm and plenty of references to his personal life and pop culture that made it easier and more fun to contribute to in-class discussions than in other classes I've taken. The workload is also super manageable as long as you're paying attention during the lectures (you generally don't need to understand the assigned readings to complete the assignments.)
Dont think there were any weaknesses.

I thought it was a very strong course overall. The lectures were engaging, and I appreciated the opportunities in class to do activities and have discussions in small groups. In addition, the readings and guest lectures were very interesting. My main piece of feedback is organizational - sometimes it was difficult to find assignments or see readings until soon before they were due, which made them harder to finish in time.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you find language interesting and want a low workload class. Also if you like thinking about words.
I would recommend this course to a student seeking a relatively low-key introduction to the field of linguistics.

I would recommend this course if you are interested in learning more about Linguistics. It's a really good introduction to the field and will give you a taste of lots of different areas so you can choose which (if any) fields you'd like to explore more of.
Yes! Its a great into course in linguistics. Although if you are looking for etymology, you wont find much of it here.
I would recommend this course if a student has some interest in linguistics that they might like to explore further.
Yes, it is a great class if you are curious to learn more about the English language.

Yes!! It's not stressful at all, but it doesn't feel like you are wasting your time. I learned a lot about the fundamentals of morphology, and I was able to apply them to random words that I would hear throughout the semester.
If this is something you're interested in then yes!
Yes! I would highly recommend if you have any interest at all in language or linguistics. The professor was very fair, assignments were straightforward, and we all learned a lot.

Yes, especially if Jim Wood is teaching. Regardless of whether you're considering a linguistics major or you're just trying to get an easy social science credit, this class would be really enjoyable. It focuses on English so you aren't at a disadvantage if you don't speak another language (in the way that you might be in some other linguistics classes) and anytime other languages were brought up in examples in class, those discussions supplemented my understanding of the content. Overall, the class is interesting, not hard and a lot of fun.
Absolutely yes. It is a very enjoyable class regardless of whether you have studied linguistics previously or not. Professor Wood is a fantastic teacher.

Yes! As a non-linguist, LING 101 was a fascinating peek into the kinds of questions linguists ask and the way they think about words, though I suspect this class would be too elementary for an experienced linguistics major. It's a low-stress, low-work class that emphasizes exploration and learning over exams and strict assignments. There's a big element of student participation in class, which is great for a class about the diversity of language. Prof Wood is clearly passionate about language, and his enthusiasm is infectious.
Yes, I would recommend this course to anyone interesting in linguistics. It was a good overview of many different topics and provided an interesting and strong foundation to linguistics as a whole.
